elements.content: An azobenzene-containing, zirconium-based metal–organic framework (AzoMOF), upon irradiation with ultraviolet (UV) light at 365 ± 10 nm, underwent trans-to-cis isomerization of its azobenzene pendants to furnish the cis-isomer content of 21% (AzoMOF21%) in 30 min at the photostationary state and underwent backward isomerization into AzoMOF1% upon either irradiation with visible light (420–480 nm) or heating. When the cis-isomer content increased, the diffusion rate and amount of CO2 adsorbed into the nanochannels of AzoMOF decreased considerably. When erythrosine B, a polarity-probing guest, was used, it showed a red shift upon exposure of AzoMOF20%⊃EB to visible light, indicating that the interior environment of AzoMOF turns less polar as the trans-isomer content becomes higher. In sharp contrast, the adsorption profiles of AzoMOF15% and AzoMOF1% for Ar having an analogous kinetic diameter to CO2 but no quadrupole moment and a smaller polarizability were virtually identical to one another. Therefore, it is likely that CO2 experiences a dominant effect of a polar effect rather than a steric effect in the crystalline nanochannels.
elements.clean_text: An azobenzene-containing, zirconium-based metal-organic framework (AzoMOF), upon irradiation with ultraviolet (UV) light at 365 ± 10 nm, underwent trans-to-cis isomerization of its azobenzene pendants to furnish the cis-isomer content of 21% (AzoMOF21%) in 30 min at the photostationary state and underwent backward isomerization into AzoMOF1% upon either irradiation with visible light (420-480 nm) or heating. When the cis-isomer content increased, the diffusion rate and amount of CO2 adsorbed into the nanochannels of AzoMOF decreased considerably. When erythrosine B, a polarity-probing guest, was used, it showed a red shift upon exposure of AzoMOF20%⊃EB to visible light, indicating that the interior environment of AzoMOF turns less polar as the trans-isomer content becomes higher. In sharp contrast, the adsorption profiles of AzoMOF15% and AzoMOF1% for Ar having an analogous kinetic diameter to CO2 but no quadrupole moment and a smaller polarizability were virtually identical to one another. Therefore, it is likely that CO2 experiences a dominant effect of a polar effect rather than a steric effect in the crystalline nanochannels.

elements.content: The integration of photoresponsive building blocks, such as azobenzene, diarylethene, aryl azide, and nitrobenzyl moieties, into metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is a leading strategy for realizing remote or noninvasive manipulation of their functions. Azobenzene derivatives are thoroughly investigated photoswitches that provide large geometrical changes based on their photochemical isomerization with ultraviolet (UV) and visible light. This isomerization could also provide a remarkable alteration in polarity because the dipole moments of the trans- and cis-isomers of nonsubstituted azobenzene are approximately zero and 3.1 D, respectively. Although several pioneering works on azobenzene-appended MOFs have been published so far, only one group claimed a polar effect based on an observation by means of quartz crystal microbalance that a MOF enhances its affinity toward butanol and butanediol vapors to some extent (5–20%) when it is exposed to UV light for inducing the trans-to-cis isomerization of the azobenzene moieties. However, to the best of our knowledge, no claim was given to how the polarity change of the channel interior upon azobenzene isomerization in MOFs affects the diffusion kinetics of gaseous molecules.
elements.clean_text: The integration of photoresponsive building blocks, such as azobenzene, diarylethene, aryl azide, and nitrobenzyl moieties, into metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is a leading strategy for realizing remote or noninvasive manipulation of their functions. Azobenzene derivatives are thoroughly investigated photoswitches that provide large geometrical changes based on their photochemical isomerization with ultraviolet (UV) and visible light. This isomerization could also provide a remarkable alteration in polarity because the dipole moments of the trans- and cis-isomers of nonsubstituted azobenzene are approximately zero and 3.1 D, respectively. Although several pioneering works on azobenzene-appended MOFs have been published so far, only one group claimed a polar effect based on an observation by means of quartz crystal microbalance that a MOF enhances its affinity toward butanol and butanediol vapors to some extent (5-20%) when it is exposed to UV light for inducing the trans-to-cis isomerization of the azobenzene moieties. However, to the best of our knowledge, no claim was given to how the polarity change of the channel interior upon azobenzene isomerization in MOFs affects the diffusion kinetics of gaseous molecules.

elements.content: Here, we report AzoMOF, a zirconium-based MOF with azobenzene pendants (Zr6O4(OH)4 L 6; L 2– = 2′-phenyldiazenyl-1,1′:4′,1″-terphenyl-4,4″-dicarboxylate, a) and its adsorption/diffusion features of gaseous molecules CO2 and Ar, in response to the photoisomerization of the azobenzene pendants. In particular, we highlight that the isomerization unprecedentedly exerts a significant effect on the diffusion kinetics of CO2 but not on that of Ar. These contrasting results are highly interesting, considering that the kinetic diameters of CO2 (3.3 Å) and Ar (3.4 Å) are substantially identical to one another and that CO2 has a quadrupole moment (−14.9 × 10–40 C m2) and a higher polarizability (29.1 × 1025 cm3) than Ar (16.4 × 1025 cm3), although both of CO2 and Ar are apolar. Erythrosine B, used as a polarity-sensitive guest molecule, allowed us to confirm that the nanochannels of AzoMOF turn more polar as their cis-isomer content increases.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report AzoMOF, a zirconium-based MOF with azobenzene pendants (Zr6O4(OH)4 L 6; L 2- = 2'-phenyldiazenyl-1,1':4',1"-terphenyl-4,4"-dicarboxylate, a) and its adsorption/diffusion features of gaseous molecules CO2 and Ar, in response to the photoisomerization of the azobenzene pendants. In particular, we highlight that the isomerization unprecedentedly exerts a significant effect on the diffusion kinetics of CO2 but not on that of Ar. These contrasting results are highly interesting, considering that the kinetic diameters of CO2 (3.3 Å) and Ar (3.4 Å) are substantially identical to one another and that CO2 has a quadrupole moment (-14.9 × 10-40 C m2) and a higher polarizability (29.1 × 1025 cm3) than Ar (16.4 × 1025 cm3), although both of CO2 and Ar are apolar. Erythrosine B, used as a polarity-sensitive guest molecule, allowed us to confirm that the nanochannels of AzoMOF turn more polar as their cis-isomer content increases.

elements.content: (a) Schematic representation of AzoMOF with azobenzene (Azo) groups as photoisomerizable pendants. The Azo groups adopting a cis configuration are highlighted with purple-colored circles. (b) Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of guest-free AzoMOF (red) and a simulated pattern for as-synthesized AzoMOF (black). The inset in panel b shows an optical image of a single crystal of AzoMOF1%. (c) 1H NMR evaluation of the trans-to-cis isomerization in AzoMOF upon irradiation with UV light (365 ± 10 nm) at 25 °C.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Schematic representation of AzoMOF with azobenzene (Azo) groups as photoisomerizable pendants. The Azo groups adopting a cis configuration are highlighted with purple-colored circles. (b) Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of guest-free AzoMOF (red) and a simulated pattern for as-synthesized AzoMOF (black). The inset in panel b shows an optical image of a single crystal of AzoMOF1%. (c) 1H NMR evaluation of the trans-to-cis isomerization in AzoMOF upon irradiation with UV light (365 ± 10 nm) at 25 °C.

elements.content: Prior to the synthesis of AzoMOF (a), we confirmed that the azobenzene pendant of its terphenylene ligand (Azo LH2) itself undergoes reversible photochemical isomerization in DMSO (Figures S4 and S5). AzoMOF was synthesized by a reaction between Azo LH2 (0.05 mmol) and ZrCl4 (0.05 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) containing a mixture of benzoic acid (1.5 mmol) and water (2 μL) at 120 °C (see Supporting Information). Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained, whereas powdery crystalline samples for spectroscopic and adsorption studies were prepared by pulverizing the single crystals (b and S7). The crystal structure (Figure S8 and Table S1) revealed that AzoMOF consists of small tetrahedral and large octahedral pores (a), which are connected only heterotropically by sharing a triangular window (b). Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy of guest-free AzoMOF upon irradiation with UV light at 365 ± 10 nm clearly showed a continuous enhancement of the n−π* transition band with the irradiation time (Figure S10a), indicating the occurrence of trans-to-cis isomerization of the azobenzene pendants in AzoMOF. Upon subsequent irradiation of AzoMOF with visible light at 420–480 nm, the azobenzene pendants isomerized back to the trans form (Figure S10b). These forward and backward isomerization events could be repeated multiple times without any noticeable fatigue and structural failure (Figures S12 and S13). The cis-azobenzene unit, attached to the pillar linker, showed a sufficiently high thermal stability at ambient temperatures with a half-life (τ1/2) of 10 days (Figure S6). By taking advantage of this geometrical stability, we successfully obtained the time-dependent isomerization profile of AzoMOF (c) by digesting the irradiated samples with DCl in DMSO-d 6 to recover Azo LH2 (Figure S11). The result indicates that the photostationary state upon UV irradiation is established in 30 min with a cis-isomer content of 21%.
elements.clean_text: Prior to the synthesis of AzoMOF (a), we confirmed that the azobenzene pendant of its terphenylene ligand (Azo LH2) itself undergoes reversible photochemical isomerization in DMSO (Figures S4 and S5). AzoMOF was synthesized by a reaction between Azo LH2 (0.05 mmol) and ZrCl4 (0.05 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) containing a mixture of benzoic acid (1.5 mmol) and water (2 μL) at 120 °C (see Supporting Information). Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained, whereas powdery crystalline samples for spectroscopic and adsorption studies were prepared by pulverizing the single crystals (b and S7). The crystal structure (Figure S8 and Table S1) revealed that AzoMOF consists of small tetrahedral and large octahedral pores (a), which are connected only heterotropically by sharing a triangular window (b). Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy of guest-free AzoMOF upon irradiation with UV light at 365 ± 10 nm clearly showed a continuous enhancement of the n-π* transition band with the irradiation time (Figure S10a), indicating the occurrence of trans-to-cis isomerization of the azobenzene pendants in AzoMOF. Upon subsequent irradiation of AzoMOF with visible light at 420-480 nm, the azobenzene pendants isomerized back to the trans form (Figure S10b). These forward and backward isomerization events could be repeated multiple times without any noticeable fatigue and structural failure (Figures S12 and S13). The cis-azobenzene unit, attached to the pillar linker, showed a sufficiently high thermal stability at ambient temperatures with a half-life (τ1/2) of 10 days (Figure S6). By taking advantage of this geometrical stability, we successfully obtained the time-dependent isomerization profile of AzoMOF (c) by digesting the irradiated samples with DCl in DMSO-d 6 to recover Azo LH2 (Figure S11). The result indicates that the photostationary state upon UV irradiation is established in 30 min with a cis-isomer content of 21%.

elements.content: (a) Single-crystal X-ray structures of tetrahedral and octahedral pores in AzoMOF. (b) Schematic illustration of the pore structures in AzoMOF. The tetrahedral and octahedral pores are highlighted in purple and green colors, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Single-crystal X-ray structures of tetrahedral and octahedral pores in AzoMOF. (b) Schematic illustration of the pore structures in AzoMOF. The tetrahedral and octahedral pores are highlighted in purple and green colors, respectively.

elements.content: We investigated the adsorption profiles of CO2 and Ar in AzoMOF1% (cis% = 1%) and AzoMOF15% (cis% = 15%), the latter of which was prepared by 30 min UV (365 ± 10 nm) irradiation of powdery AzoMOF1% (30 mg) sandwiched between two glass plates as illustrated in c (inset). Just like other zirconium-based MOFs with two different-sized pores, both AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue) showed a stepwise adsorption isotherm for CO2 at 195 K with a clear inflection point at P/P 0 = 0.15 for the secondary adsorption to occur (P = equilibrium vapor pressure, P 0 = saturated vapor pressure) (a). According to the reported examples, the primary and secondary adsorption features in a are assignable to the pore-filling processes for the tetrahedral and octahedral pores with CO2, respectively. The important observation here was a marked decrease in the amount of adsorbed CO2 upon photochemical conversion of AzoMOF1% (black) into AzoMOF15% (blue). For Ar, a stepwise adsorption isotherm was likewise observed for AzoMOF1% and AzoMOF15% at 87 K (b), though in a much narrower P/P 0 range, with an inflection point at P/P 0 = 0.01 (b, inset). However, in contrast to the case of CO2, the adsorption profile of Ar barely changed upon photochemical conversion of AzoMOF1% (black) into AzoMOF15% (blue). Accordingly, the pore size distribution (Figure S9) and Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) surface areas, evaluated with Ar for AzoMOF1% (1412 m2 g–1) and AzoMOF15% (1418 m2 g–1), were substantially identical to one another.

Just like other zirconium-based MOFs with two different-sized pores, both AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue) showed a stepwise adsorption isotherm for CO2 at 195 K with a clear inflection point at P/P 0 = 0.15 for the secondary adsorption to occur (P = equilibrium vapor pressure, P 0 = saturated vapor pressure) (a). According to the reported examples, the primary and secondary adsorption features in a are assignable to the pore-filling processes for the tetrahedral and octahedral pores with CO2, respectively. The important observation here was a marked decrease in the amount of adsorbed CO2 upon photochemical conversion of AzoMOF1% (black) into AzoMOF15% (blue). For Ar, a stepwise adsorption isotherm was likewise observed for AzoMOF1% and AzoMOF15% at 87 K (b), though in a much narrower P/P 0 range, with an inflection point at P/P 0 = 0.01 (b, inset). However, in contrast to the case of CO2, the adsorption profile of Ar barely changed upon photochemical conversion of AzoMOF1% (black) into AzoMOF15% (blue). Accordingly, the pore size distribution (Figure S9) and Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface areas, evaluated with Ar for AzoMOF1% (1412 m2 g-1) and AzoMOF15% (1418 m2 g-1), were substantially identical to one another.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms of (a) CO2 at 195 K and (b) Ar at 87 K in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively, where the inflection points for the secondary adsorption to start appear at P/P 0 = 0.15 and 0.01, respectively. The inset in panel b shows adsorption isotherms of Ar enlarged in a range of P/P 0 from 0 to 0.06. Diffusion rate constants for (c) CO2 (P/P 0 = 0–0.2) and (d) Ar (P/P 0 = 0–0.02) through the triangular windows (w k d) in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively. Diffusion rate constants for (e) CO2 (P/P 0 = 0–0.2) and (f) Ar (P/P 0 = 0–0.02) within the polyhedral pores (p k d) in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  Adsorption isotherms of (a) CO2 at 195 K and (b) Ar at 87 K in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively, where the inflection points for the secondary adsorption to start appear at P/P 0 = 0.15 and 0.01, respectively. The inset in panel b shows adsorption isotherms of Ar enlarged in a range of P/P 0 from 0 to 0.06. Diffusion rate constants for (c) CO2 (P/P 0 = 0-0.2) and (d) Ar (P/P 0 = 0-0.02) through the triangular windows (w k d) in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively. Diffusion rate constants for (e) CO2 (P/P 0 = 0-0.2) and (f) Ar (P/P 0 = 0-0.02) within the polyhedral pores (p k d) in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively.

elements.content: As described in the introductory part, the dipole moment of cis-azobenzene is approximately 3.1 D, whereas that of its trans isomer is nearly zero. Hence, AzoMOF15% likely provides more polar crystalline channels than AzoMOF1% does. Because of its quadrupole moment and polarizability, CO2 may possibly interact with polar motifs by a dipole/quadrupole interaction, so that AzoMOF15% with a higher cis-isomer content likely interacts with CO2 more preferentially than AzoMOF1%. To support this hypothesis, we used erythrosine B (EB) as a guest molecule to explore the change in the interior polarity of AzoMOF as a function of the cis-isomer content. EB is known to serve as a polarity-sensitive probe and exhibits a red shift in its absorption when located in a less polar environment. Thus, EB-containing AzoMOF20% (AzoMOF20%⊃EB) was prepared according to the procedure in a, where the amount of EB loaded in AzoMOF20%, as estimated by electronic absorption spectroscopy, was 0.5 wt % (Figure S14). Upon 2 h irradiation of AzoMOF20%⊃EB with visible light (420–480 nm), the diffuse reflectance spectroscopy clearly showed a red shift in a range from 470 to 600 nm (b). Note that neither AzoMOF20% without EB (Figure S10b) nor EB alone (Figure S15) showed any appreciable red shift upon irradiation with visible light.
elements.clean_text: As described in the introductory part, the dipole moment of cis-azobenzene is approximately 3.1 D, whereas that of its trans isomer is nearly zero. Hence, AzoMOF15% likely provides more polar crystalline channels than AzoMOF1% does. Because of its quadrupole moment and polarizability, CO2 may possibly interact with polar motifs by a dipole/quadrupole interaction, so that AzoMOF15% with a higher cis-isomer content likely interacts with CO2 more preferentially than AzoMOF1%. To support this hypothesis, we used erythrosine B (EB) as a guest molecule to explore the change in the interior polarity of AzoMOF as a function of the cis-isomer content. EB is known to serve as a polarity-sensitive probe and exhibits a red shift in its absorption when located in a less polar environment. Thus, EB-containing AzoMOF20% (AzoMOF20%⊃EB) was prepared according to the procedure in a, where the amount of EB loaded in AzoMOF20%, as estimated by electronic absorption spectroscopy, was 0.5 wt % (Figure S14). Upon 2 h irradiation of AzoMOF20%⊃EB with visible light (420-480 nm), the diffuse reflectance spectroscopy clearly showed a red shift in a range from 470 to 600 nm (b). Note that neither AzoMOF20% without EB (Figure S10b) nor EB alone (Figure S15) showed any appreciable red shift upon irradiation with visible light.

elements.content: (a) Schematic representation of the procedure for including EB into AzoMOF20% (AzoMOF20%⊃EB): Powdery AzoMOF20% was immersed in an EtOH solution of EB for 12 h in the dark, isolated by filtration, rinsed with EtOH, and then vacuum-dried in the dark. The mole ratio of incorporated EB relative to Azo L 2– was 1/330. (b) Diffuse reflectance spectra of AzoMOF20%⊃EB before (blue) and after (black) the irradiation with visible light for 2 h at 25 °C.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Schematic representation of the procedure for including EB into AzoMOF20% (AzoMOF20%⊃EB): Powdery AzoMOF20% was immersed in an EtOH solution of EB for 12 h in the dark, isolated by filtration, rinsed with EtOH, and then vacuum-dried in the dark. The mole ratio of incorporated EB relative to Azo L 2- was 1/330. (b) Diffuse reflectance spectra of AzoMOF20%⊃EB before (blue) and after (black) the irradiation with visible light for 2 h at 25 °C.

elements.content: AzoMOF adopts only a face-to-face heterotropic connection between the tetrahedral and octahedral pores by sharing a triangular window (), where the diffusion event through the triangular window is likely more sluggish than those in the polyhedral pores. Furthermore, because the azobenzene pendants are localized on the window frames (Figure S8), the diffusion event through the window might be more influenced by the isomer ratio of the azobenzene pendants. Hence, for the kinetic analysis of the adsorption profiles in a,b, we used the following double-exponential equation featuring w k d and p k d as variables, which are supposed to be the diffusion rate constants of gaseous molecules through the triangular windows and within the polyhedral pores, respectively: M t / M e = A 1 [ 1 − exp ( − k d w t ) ] + A 2 [ 1 − exp ( − k d p t ) ] where M t and M e represent the amounts of gas molecules adsorbed at time t, and equilibrium, respectively; whereas A 1 and A 2 denote relative contributions of the triangular window and polyhedral pores to the overall diffusion process, with A 1 + A 2 = 1. As summarized in Tables S2–S5, fitting each kinetic profile using forgoing equation gave a sequence of values for two diffusion rate constants w k d and p k d (Figure S17). As expected, irrespective of the cis-isomer content of AzoMOF, the w k d values for both CO2 (c,e) and Ar (d,f) are much smaller than the corresponding p k d values in the whole range of P/P 0. Of particular interest, the w k d values for CO2 in AzoMOF15% (blue) are 1 order of magnitude smaller than those in AzoMOF1% (black) (c). In sharp contrast, the p k d values for CO2 in AzoMOF15% (blue) and AzoMOF1% (black) are almost identical to one another (e). Namely, the cis-isomer content in AzoMOF influences mostly on the diffusion event through the triangular window. Meanwhile, as shown in d,f, such a site-specific effect of the azobenzene isomer content on the diffusion process (black and blue) was not observed for Ar possibly due to the lack of permanent dipole and quadrupole moment. A lower polarizability of Ar than CO2 might also be partly responsible for this tendency. Together with the facts that the kinetic diameters of CO2 and Ar are substantially identical to one another and that the azobenzene pendants are localized on the window frames (Figure S8), the marked difference in the w k d values for CO2 between AzoMOF1% and AzoMOF15% (w k d in AzoMOF1% ≫ w k d in AzoMOF15%) suggests that CO2 dominantly receives a polar effect, rather than a steric effect, from the azobenzene pendants when it diffuses through the triangular windows in AzoMOF. Consistent with this observation, the isosteric heat of the adsorption of CO2 in AzoMOF15% was estimated as 38 kJ mol–1 at zero coverage, which is larger than that in AzoMOF1% (29 kJ mol–1) (Figure S18), indicating a higher affinity of CO2 toward AzoMOF15% than AzoMOF1%. Then, here comes a question that why the amount of adsorbed CO2 in AzoMOF15% is smaller than that in AzoMOF1%. Physical properties of CO2 in the condensed state, gathering via a quadrupole/quadrupole interaction, could be affected by coexisting polar groups in a congested space. In fact, surface groups in such crystalline nanochannels were reported to affect the packing mode of condensed gaseous molecules. We suppose that this is also the case in the crystalline nanochannels of AzoMOF, where the packing mode and thus the density of CO2 would change with the polarity of the channel wall, i.e., the cis-isomer content of the azobenzene pendants.
elements.clean_text: AzoMOF adopts only a face-to-face heterotropic connection between the tetrahedral and octahedral pores by sharing a triangular window (), where the diffusion event through the triangular window is likely more sluggish than those in the polyhedral pores. Furthermore, because the azobenzene pendants are localized on the window frames (Figure S8), the diffusion event through the window might be more influenced by the isomer ratio of the azobenzene pendants. Hence, for the kinetic analysis of the adsorption profiles in a,b, we used the following double-exponential equation featuring w k d and p k d as variables, which are supposed to be the diffusion rate constants of gaseous molecules through the triangular windows and within the polyhedral pores, respectively:        M   t   /   M   e   =   A   1    [ 1 - exp  ( -     k   d       w   t )  ]  +   A   2    [ 1 - exp  ( -     k   d       p   t )  ]     1 where M  t  and M e represent the amounts of gas molecules adsorbed at time t, and equilibrium, respectively; whereas A 1 and A 2 denote relative contributions of the triangular window and polyhedral pores to the overall diffusion process, with A 1 + A 2 = 1. As summarized in Tables S2-S5, fitting each kinetic profile using forgoing equation gave a sequence of values for two diffusion rate constants w k d and p k d (Figure S17). As expected, irrespective of the cis-isomer content of AzoMOF, the w k d values for both CO2 (c,e) and Ar (d,f) are much smaller than the corresponding p k d values in the whole range of P/P 0. Of particular interest, the w k d values for CO2 in AzoMOF15% (blue) are 1 order of magnitude smaller than those in AzoMOF1% (black) (c). In sharp contrast, the p k d values for CO2 in AzoMOF15% (blue) and AzoMOF1% (black) are almost identical to one another (e). Namely, the cis-isomer content in AzoMOF influences mostly on the diffusion event through the triangular window. Meanwhile, as shown in d,f, such a site-specific effect of the azobenzene isomer content on the diffusion process (black and blue) was not observed for Ar possibly due to the lack of permanent dipole and quadrupole moment. A lower polarizability of Ar than CO2 might also be partly responsible for this tendency. Together with the facts that the kinetic diameters of CO2 and Ar are substantially identical to one another and that the azobenzene pendants are localized on the window frames (Figure S8), the marked difference in the w k d values for CO2 between AzoMOF1% and AzoMOF15% (w k d in AzoMOF1% ≫ w k d in AzoMOF15%) suggests that CO2 dominantly receives a polar effect, rather than a steric effect, from the azobenzene pendants when it diffuses through the triangular windows in AzoMOF. Consistent with this observation, the isosteric heat of the adsorption of CO2 in AzoMOF15% was estimated as 38 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage, which is larger than that in AzoMOF1% (29 kJ mol-1) (Figure S18), indicating a higher affinity of CO2 toward AzoMOF15% than AzoMOF1%. Then, here comes a question that why the amount of adsorbed CO2 in AzoMOF15% is smaller than that in AzoMOF1%. Physical properties of CO2 in the condensed state, gathering via a quadrupole/quadrupole interaction, could be affected by coexisting polar groups in a congested space. In fact, surface groups in such crystalline nanochannels were reported to affect the packing mode of condensed gaseous molecules. We suppose that this is also the case in the crystalline nanochannels of AzoMOF, where the packing mode and thus the density of CO2 would change with the polarity of the channel wall, i.e., the cis-isomer content of the azobenzene pendants.

elements.content: In conclusion, we demonstrated that AzoMOF provides the first porous crystalline nanochannel that photochemically modulates the diffusion kinetics of CO2 by alteration of the polar interaction with the azobenzene-appended channel wall. The use of polarity-sensitive EB, together with Ar with no quadrupole moment as a similar-sized reference to CO2, nicely supported the above conclusion. Design of MOFs with other photochromic molecules is an interesting subject worthy of further investigations.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we demonstrated that AzoMOF provides the first porous crystalline nanochannel that photochemically modulates the diffusion kinetics of CO2 by alteration of the polar interaction with the azobenzene-appended channel wall. The use of polarity-sensitive EB, together with Ar with no quadrupole moment as a similar-sized reference to CO2, nicely supported the above conclusion. Design of MOFs with other photochromic molecules is an interesting subject worthy of further investigations.

(b) Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of guest-free AzoMOF (red) and a simulated pattern for as-synthesized AzoMOF (black). The inset in panel b shows an optical image of a single crystal of AzoMOF1%. (c) 1H NMR evaluation of the trans-to-cis isomerization in AzoMOF upon irradiation with UV light (365 ± 10 nm) at 25 °C.

cln_elements.content: (a) Single-crystal X-ray structures of tetrahedral and octahedral pores in AzoMOF. (b) Schematic illustration of the pore structures in AzoMOF. The tetrahedral and octahedral pores are highlighted in purple and green colors, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Single-crystal X-ray structures of tetrahedral and octahedral pores in AzoMOF. (b) Schematic illustration of the pore structures in AzoMOF. The tetrahedral and octahedral pores are highlighted in purple and green colors, respectively.

cln_elements.content: Adsorption isotherms of (a) CO2 at 195 K and (b) Ar at 87 K in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively, where the inflection points for the secondary adsorption to start appear at P/P 0 = 0.15 and 0.01, respectively. The inset in panel b shows adsorption isotherms of Ar enlarged in a range of P/P 0 from 0 to 0.06. Diffusion rate constants for (c) CO2 (P/P 0 = 0–0.2) and (d) Ar (P/P 0 = 0–0.02) through the triangular windows (w k d) in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively. Diffusion rate constants for (e) CO2 (P/P 0 = 0–0.2) and (f) Ar (P/P 0 = 0–0.02) within the polyhedral pores (p k d) in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Adsorption isotherms of (a) CO2 at 195 K and (b) Ar at 87 K in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively, where the inflection points for the secondary adsorption to start appear at P/P 0 = 0.15 and 0.01, respectively. The inset in panel b shows adsorption isotherms of Ar enlarged in a range of P/P 0 from 0 to 0.06. Diffusion rate constants for (c) CO2 (P/P 0 = 0-0.2) and (d) Ar (P/P 0 = 0-0.02) through the triangular windows (w k d) in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively. Diffusion rate constants for (e) CO2 (P/P 0 = 0-0.2) and (f) Ar (P/P 0 = 0-0.02) within the polyhedral pores (p k d) in AzoMOF1% (black) and AzoMOF15% (blue), respectively.

cln_elements.content: (a) Schematic representation of the procedure for including EB into AzoMOF20% (AzoMOF20%⊃EB): Powdery AzoMOF20% was immersed in an EtOH solution of EB for 12 h in the dark, isolated by filtration, rinsed with EtOH, and then vacuum-dried in the dark. The mole ratio of incorporated EB relative to Azo L 2– was 1/330. (b) Diffuse reflectance spectra of AzoMOF20%⊃EB before (blue) and after (black) the irradiation with visible light for 2 h at 25 °C.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Schematic representation of the procedure for including EB into AzoMOF20% (AzoMOF20%⊃EB): Powdery AzoMOF20% was immersed in an EtOH solution of EB for 12 h in the dark, isolated by filtration, rinsed with EtOH, and then vacuum-dried in the dark. The mole ratio of incorporated EB relative to Azo L 2- was 1/330. (b) Diffuse reflectance spectra of AzoMOF20%⊃EB before (blue) and after (black) the irradiation with visible light for 2 h at 25 °C.

metadata.title:
Crystalline
Nanochannels with Pendant Azobenzene Groups:
Steric or Polar Effects on Gas Adsorption and Diffusion?
